column1: lunamalfoy7 161076432023 "2017-05-26 01:00:41 GMT" https://lunamalfoy7.tumblr.com/post/161076432023/cakecourse-bracelet00-cakecourse-can-we "cakecourse: bracelet00:  cakecourse:  Can we normalize the idea that women can have deep voices? please??  Especially for trans women who feel gross or out of place for their deep voice.  Please
column2: break the standard that all women have high pitched
column3: perfect
column4: feminine voices.  My car got towed on NYE
column5: so after unsuccessfully trying every number programmed into my phone
column6: I called my dadâ€™s ass up at 2 AM to pick up myself and my friends to go get my vehicle out of impound (my dad is awesome. More on that later.)  Included in my group of friends was my friend Anna who had recently come forward as trans. She had very recently started presenting as a woman
column7: and was pretty insecure in it
column8: and had never met my father previously
column9: so it wasnâ€™t as though I had time to brief him on the situation. Anna was pretty shy during the whole ride
column10: tucked in the back and letting her friends talk over her. She only spoke up after I had gotten my car back
column11: thanking him for helping out. The next day
column12: I called to thank him for that night
column13: and he asked me who was the girl with the deep voice. At first my heart sink in my guts
column15: he started raving about how he LOVED her voice. He listed off a few actresses from his day who had had very deep voices
column17: and that kind of slow sultry speaking had been fading more and more as pop culture pushed for childish voices in women. Your deep voice is gorgeous trans friends (and cis friends too.) it is warm and low and smooth like honey and perfect in every way. It is smoldering and evocative and absolutely beautiful.  Honestly this is the most beautiful story ever
column18: Iâ€™ve read it like 5 times over. Thank you so much for this. " False text

column1: lunamalfoy7 160983409898 "2017-05-23 13:00:15 GMT" https://lunamalfoy7.tumblr.com/post/160983409898/the-killing-joke-doesnt-deserve-the-credit-for "dr-archeville:  Alan Moore and Brian Bollandâ€™s classic and controversial Batman: The Killing Joke is making waves once again after the the animated adaptation debuted at San Diego Comic Con and reportedly doubled down on the damseling and objectification of Batgirl.Â  Without spoiling the changes (you can read about them here)
column2: Barbara Gordonâ€™s reliance on menâ€™s approval is a big theme of the film
column3: and only serves to give Batman more angst when the events of the comic  play out. Fans of The Killing Joke will often defend it by pointing out that without the story

column5: the Batman familyâ€™s computer whiz and one of the most prominent disabled superheroes in comic books.Â  However
column6: crediting The Killing Joke for the creation of Oracle is wholly inaccurate and does a disservice to the true creators of the reinvention
column7: John Ostrander and Kim Yale. (Note: This article contains some language that readers may find upsetting.) The reinvention of Barbara Gordon as Oracle is often attributed to  Moore and Bolland
column8: and as such the trauma and objectification she  endures in The Killing Joke are seen as justified.Â  According this argument
column10: and Killing Joke should be lauded for everything that happened to Barbara Gordon afterwards. That  couldnâ€™t be further from the truth
column11: and Alan Moore has gone record  saying that Barabaâ€™s trauma was an afterthought.Â  Quite famously
column12: he  approached his editor Len Wein with the idea
column16: cripple the bitchâ€. Brian Croninâ€™s A (Perhaps Unnecessary) Guide to Oracleâ€™s Formative Years  goes into more detail about the timeline of Barbara Gordonâ€™s  transformation into Oracle
column17: and with one quote from John Ostrander
column18: proves itself to indeed be very necessary. â€œThere were no plans for her in the continuity at that  time.Â  We decided that if that happened
column19: we werenâ€™t just going to make  her better magically â€” we wanted to explore what happened when someone  like her was crippled and how she would respond.â€ By the time The Killing Joke happened
column20: Barbara Gordon had  retired as Batgirl and was living a peaceful civilian life.Â  She was  revived by Moore and Bolland solely to be assaulted â€” grievously and  sexually â€” by The Joker
column21: all as part of his effort to get to her father and
column23: Batman. There is a concept called the â€œSexy Lamp test

column25: that  says If you can take out a female character out of a story and replace  her with a sexy lamp you are
column27: â€œa fâ€”â€” hack!â€. So letâ€™s apply that to The Killing Joke.Â  Barbara Gordon is nothing more than a sexy lamp to Commissioner Gordon  and Batman
column28: an object that they like a lot
